</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-LEFT: 14.2PT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; MARGIN-RIGHT: 10.2PT">
	(1)&#160; Represents amounts due under our banking facilities agreements, without considering the
<FONT ID="TRGRRTFTOHTMLTAB" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	repayment on demand clause.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-LEFT: 14.2PT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; MARGIN-RIGHT: 10.2PT">
	(2)&#160; Includes interest payment.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	For a discussion of interest rates on our notes payable and bank loans, see Item 11. &#8211; &#8220;Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures About Market Risk,&#8221; below.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Critical Accounting Policies
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The methods, estimates and judgments we use in applying our most critical accounting policies have a significant impact on the results we report in our financial statements.&#160; The SEC has defined the most critical accounting policies as the ones that are most important to the portrayal of our financial condition and results and require us to make our most difficult and subjective judgments, often as a result of the need to make estimates of matters that are inherently uncertain.&#160; Based on this definition, our most critical policies include valuation of inventories, revenue recognition, impairment of long-lived assets, stock-based compensation, allowance for trade receivables and income and deferred income taxes.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Below, we discuss these policies further, as well as the estimates and judgments involved.&#160; We believe that our other policies either do not generally require us to make estimates and judgments that are as difficult or as subjective, or it is less likely that they would have a material impact on our reported results of operations for a given period.&#160; For a discussion of all our significant accounting policies, see footnote 1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	46
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage47"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Valuation of Inventories
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value with cost determined on a first-in, first-out basis.&#160; Net realizable value is the price at which inventories can be sold in the normal course of business after allowing for the costs of completion and disposal.&#160; The Company continuously reviews slow-moving and obsolete inventory and assesses any inventory obsolescence based on inventory levels, material composition and expected usage as of that date.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Revenue Recognition
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	No revenue is recognized unless there is persuasive evidence of an arrangement, the price to the buyer is fixed or determinable, delivery has occurred and collectability of the sales price is reasonably assured.&#160; Revenue is recognized when title and risk of loss transfers to the customer, which is generally when the product is leaving the port of Hong Kong, Shenzhen or Guangzhou as designated by our customers. Shipping costs billed to our customers are included within revenue.&#160; Associated costs are classified in cost of sales.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The Company provides to certain customers an additional one to two percent of certain products ordered in lieu of a warranty, which are recognized as cost of sales when these products are shipped to customers from our facilities.&#160; In addition, certain products sold by the Company are subject to a limited product quality warranty.&#160; The Company accrues for estimated incurred but unidentified quality issues based upon historical activity and known quality issues if a loss is probable and can be reasonably estimated.&#160; The standard limited warranty period is one to three years.&#160; Quality returns, refunds, rebates and discounts are recorded net of sales if they are within the warranty period.&#160; All sales are based upon firm orders with fixed terms and conditions, which generally cannot be modified.&#160; Historically, we have not experienced material differences between our estimated amounts of quality returns, refunds, rebates and discounts and the actual results.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Rental income is recognized according to the rental agreements.&#160; Rental income for non-uniform rent payments is recognized on a straight-line basis throughout the lease term.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Impairment of Long-Lived Assets and Intangible Assets
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Long-lived assets held and used by the Company and intangible assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable.&#160; The Company evaluates recoverability of assets to be held and used by comparing the carrying amount of an asset to future net undiscounted cash flows to be generated by the asset.&#160; If such assets are considered to be impaired, the impairment loss is measured by the amount by which the carrying amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the assets calculated using a discounted future cash flows analysis.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	47
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage48"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-LEFT: 36PT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: -36PT">
	Stock-based Compensation
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT">
	The Company follows the guidance of ASC 718, &#8220;Accounting for Stock Options and Other Stock-Based Compensation.&#8221;&#160; ASC 718 requires companies to record compensation expense for share-based awards issued to employees and directors in exchange for services provided.&#160; The amount of the compensation expense is based on the estimated fair value of the awards on their grant dates and is recognized over the required service periods. Our share-based awards include stock options and restricted stock awards.&#160; The estimated fair value underlying our calculation of compensation expense for stock options is based on the Black-Scholes pricing model. Forfeitures of share-based awards are estimated at the time of grant and revised, if necessary, in subsequent periods if our estimates change based on the actual amount of forfeitures we have experienced.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-LEFT: 36PT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: -36PT">
	Trade Receivables
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 35.45PT">
	Allowance is made against trade receivables to the extent that collection is considered to be doubtful.&#160; This allowance is primarily determined from our monthly aging analysis.&#160; It also requires judgment regarding the collectability of certain receivables, as certain receivables may be identified as collectible that are subsequently uncollectible and which could result in a subsequent write-off of the related receivable to the statement of operations.&#160; Most of the Company&#8217;s trade receivables are generally unsecured.&#160; To determine the necessity of a provision, the Company analyzes the age of the receivables and the customer&#8217;s ability to pay based on past payment history, financial statements and various information of the customer.&#160;&#160; Any change in the collectability of accounts receivable that were not previously provided for could significantly change the calculation of such provision and the results of our operations.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Income and Deferred Income Taxes
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The Company complies with ASC 740 which prescribes a recognition threshold and measurement attributes for the financial statement recognition and measurement of a tax position taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.&#160; ASC 740 also provides guidance on derecognition, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, disclosure and transition.&#160; Only tax positions that meet the more-likely-than-not recognition threshold at the effective date may be recognized or continue to be recognized upon adoption of ASC 740.&#160; The Company&#8217;s accounting policy is to treat interest and penalties as a component of income taxes.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Amounts in the consolidated financial statements related to income taxes are calculated using the principles of ASC 740 and ASU 2013-11 &#8220;Presentation of an Unrecognized Tax Benefit When a Net Operating Loss Carryforward, a Similar Tax Loss, or a Tax Credit Carryforward Exists.&#8221;&#160; ASC 740 requires recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of events that have been included in the financial statements or tax returns.&#160; Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on the temporary differences between the financial reporting basis and the tax basis of assets and liabilities using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to reverse.&#160; Future tax benefits, such as net operating loss carry forwards, are recognized as deferred tax assets.&#160; Recognized deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if, based on the weight of available evidence, it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	48
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage49"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Trend Information
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Although we are optimistic about our future in the manufacture and sale of sensor-based scales products, we are dependent upon a limited number of customers for a significant portion of our revenues, and the loss of any of these customers could have a material adverse effect upon us and our results of operations.&#160; As of March 31, 2016, our backlog of manufacturing orders was $3,864,000&#160; as compared to $4,581,000 as of March 31, 2015.&#160; We expect that the demand for our products will decrease in the fiscal year ending March 31, 2017, compared with that in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2016 as a result of an expected lower overall demand for our products.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	We do not have any off-balance sheet arrangements that have, or are reasonably likely to have, a current or future effect on our financial condition, changes in financial condition, revenues or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures or capital resources that are material to investors.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Recent Accounting Pronouncements
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The new accounting pronouncements in the United States that may be relevant to the Group are as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-09, &#8220;Revenue from Contracts with Customers&#8221; (&#8220;ASU 2014-09&#8221;).&#160; The objective of this Update is to remove inconsistencies and weaknesses in revenue requirements, and to simplify the preparation of financial statements by reducing the number requirements to which an entity must refer.&#160; The new standard supersedes virtually all present U.S. GAAP guidance on revenue recognition and requires the use of more estimates and judgments than the present standards, as well as additional disclosures. In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-14, "Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Deferral of the Effective Date", deferring the effective date for one year to interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2017. Early adoption is also permitted as of the original effective date (interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016) and retrospective application is required. The Company is currently evaluating the impact this Update will have on its consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In June 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-12, &#8220;Compensation - Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Accounting for Share-Based Payments When the Terms of an Award Provide That a Performance Target Could Be Achieved after the Requisite Service Period&#8221; (&#8220;ASU 2014-12&#8221;). The amendments in ASU 2014-12 require that a performance target that affects vesting and that could be achieved after the requisite service period be treated as a performance condition. The amendments in this ASU are effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2015, including interim periods within that reporting period, with early application permitted. Companies may use either a prospective or a retrospective approach to adopt this ASU and the Company is currently evaluating which transition approach to use.&#160; The adoption of ASU 2014-12 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	49
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In August 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-15, &#8220;Disclosure of Uncertainties about an Entity&#8217;s Ability to Continue as a Going Concern,&#8221; which provides guidance on determining when and how to disclose going-concern uncertainties in the financial statements.&#160; The new standard requires management to perform interim and annual assessments of an entity&#8217;s ability to continue as a going concern within one year of the date the financial statements are issued.&#160; An entity must provide certain disclosures if conditions or events raise substantial doubt about the entity&#8217;s ability to continue as a going concern.&#160; The ASU applies to all entities and is effective for annual periods ending after December 15, 2016, and interim periods thereafter, with early adoption permitted.&#160; The Company is currently evaluating the impact this Update will have on its consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In January 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-01, &#8220;Income Statement - Extraordinary and Unusual Items (Subtopic 225-20): Simplifying Income Statement Presentation by Eliminating the Concept of Extraordinary Items&#8221; (&#8220;ASU 2015-01&#8221;).&#160; The amendments in ASU 2015-01 eliminate from U.S. GAAP the concept of extraordinary items. The amendments in this ASU are effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2015, including interim periods within that reporting period, with early application permitted provided that the guidance is applied from the beginning of the fiscal year of adoption. Companies may use either a prospective or a retrospective approach to adopt this ASU and the Company is currently evaluating which transition approach to use. The adoption of ASU 2015-01 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In February 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-02, &#8220;Consolidation (Topic 810): Amendments to the Consolidation Analysis&#8221; (&#8220;ASU 2015-02&#8221;). The amendments in ASU 2015-02 change the analysis that a reporting entity must perform to determine whether it should consolidate certain types of legal entities. The amendments in this ASU are effective for public business entities for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2015, and for interim periods within those fiscal years. Early adoption is permitted, including adoption in an interim period. If an entity early adopts the amendments in an interim period, any adjustments should be reflected as of the beginning of the fiscal year that includes that interim period. A reporting entity may apply the amendments in this ASU using a modified retrospective approach by recording a cumulative-effect adjustment to equity as of the beginning of the fiscal year of adoption. A reporting entity also may apply the amendments retrospectively. The adoption of ASU 2015-02 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In April 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-03, &#8220;Simplifying the Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs,&#8221; (&#8220;ASU 2015-03&#8221;) which changes the presentation of debt issuance costs in financial statements. ASU 2015-03 requires an entity to present such costs in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the related debt liability rather than as an asset. Amortization of the costs will continue to be reported as interest expense. The guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2015, with early adoption permitted.&#160; The adoption of ASU 2015-03 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements or disclosures.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	50
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage51"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In April 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-05, &#8220;Customer&#8217;s Accounting for Fees Paid in a Cloud Computing Arrangement&#8221; (&#8220;ASU 2015-05&#8221;) (an update to Subtopic 350-40, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other - Internal-Use Software), which provides guidance on accounting for cloud computing fees. If a cloud computing arrangement includes a software license, then the customer should account for the license element of the arrangement consistent with the acquisition of other software licenses. If a cloud computing arrangement does not include a software license, the arrangement should be accounted for as a service contract. This ASU is effective for arrangements entered into, or materially modified, in interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015. Retrospective application is permitted but not required.&#160; The adoption of ASU 2015-05 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements or disclosures.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In May 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-07, &#8220;Fair Value Measurement: Disclosures for Investments in Certain Entities That Calculate Net Asset Value per Share (or Its Equivalent)&#8221; (&#8220;ASU 2015-07&#8221;), which removes the requirement to categorize within the fair value hierarchy all investments for which fair value is measured using the net asset value per share practical expedient. The ASU also removes the requirement to make certain disclosures for all investments that are eligible to be measured at fair value using the net asset value per share practical expedient. Rather, those disclosures are limited to investments for which the entity has elected to measure the fair value using that practical expedient. This ASU is effective for arrangements entered into, or materially modified, in interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015. Retrospective application is permitted but not required. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this ASU on the consolidated financial statements. The adoption of ASU 2015-07 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements or disclosures.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-11, "Inventory (Topic 330): Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory" ("ASU 2015-11"), which states an entity should measure inventory at the lower of cost and net realizable value. Net realizable value is the estimated selling prices in the ordinary course of business, less reasonably predictable costs of completion, disposal and transportation. This amendment applies to all inventory that is measured using the average costs or first-in first-out (FIFO) methods. This supersedes prior guidance which allowed entities to measure inventory at the lower of cost or market, where market could be replacement cost, net realizable value or net realizable value less an approximately normal profit margin. This ASU is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016. The amendments should be applied prospectively and earlier application is permitted. This ASU is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-17, "Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes" ("ASU 2015-17"). The amendments in this update require that deferred tax liabilities and assets be classified as noncurrent in a classified statement of financial position. For public business entities, the amendments in this Update are effective for financial statements issued for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods. Earlier application is permitted for all entities as of the beginning of an interim or annual reporting period. The Company is evaluating the new pronouncement to determine the impact it may have to its consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	51
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage52"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In January 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-01, "Financial Instruments&#8212;Overall (Subtopic 825-10): Recognition and Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities" ("ASU 2016-01"). The amendments in this update supersede the guidance to classify equity securities with readily determinable fair values into different categories (that is trading or available-for-sale) and require equity securities (including other ownership interests, such as partnerships, unincorporated joint ventures, and limited liability companies) to be measured at fair value with changes in the fair value recognized through net income. For public business entities, the amendments in this Update are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within those fiscal years. The Company is evaluating the new pronouncement to determine the impact it may have to its consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02, "Lease (Subtopic 842)" ("ASU 2016-02"): This Update is to increase transparency and comparability among organizations by recognizing lease assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet and disclosing key information about leasing arrangements. For public business entities, this Update is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years. The Company is evaluating the new pronouncement to determine the impact it may have to its consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In March 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-05, "Derivatives and Hedging: Effect of Derivative Contract Novations on Existing Hedge Accounting Relationships" ("ASU 2016-05"), which states that a change in counterparty to a derivative instrument does not, in and of itself, require dedesignation of that hedging relationship provided that all other hedge account criteria continue to be met. This ASU is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016. The amendments should be applied on either a prospective basis or a modified retrospective basis and earlier application is permitted. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this ASU on the consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In March 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-09, "Compensation &#8211; Stock Compensation: Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting" ("ASU 2016-09"), which provides guidance on several aspects of accounting for share-based payment transactions, including the accounting for income taxes, forfeitures, and statutory tax withholding requirements, as well as classification on the statement of cash flows. Most notably, the Company will be required to recognize all excess tax benefits and shortfalls as income tax expense or benefit in the statement of earnings within the reporting period in which they occur. This ASU is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016 and early addition is permitted. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this ASU on the consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-13, "Financial Instruments&#8212;Credit Losses (Topic 326): Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments" ("ASU 2016-13"), which improves financial reporting by providing timelier recording of credit losses on loans and other financial instruments held by financial institutions and other organizations. The ASU requires an organization to measure all expected credit losses for financial assets held at the reporting date based on historical experience, current conditions, and reasonable and supportable forecasts. Forward-looking information will now be used to better inform credit loss estimates. This ASU is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2019 and early addition is permitted. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this ASU on its consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	We believe there is no additional new accounting guidance adopted, but not yet effective that is relevant to the readers of our financial statements.&#160; However, there are numerous new proposals under development which, if and when enacted, may have a significant impact on our financial reporting.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	52
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	ANTHONY SO is the founder of Bonso.&#160; He has been our Chairman of the Board of Directors since July 1988.&#160; He was appointed as the Chief Executive Officer and President on November 16, 2006, and served in those capacities until March 20, 2015 when Andrew So was appointed President.&#160; Mr. So received his BSE degree in civil engineering from National Taiwan University in 1967 and a Master degree in Business Administration (&#8220;MBA&#8221;) from the Hong Kong campus of the University of Hull, Hull, England in 1994.&#160; Mr. So has been Chairman of the Hong Kong GO Association since 1986 and also served as Chairman of the Alumni Association of National Taiwan University for the 1993-1994 academic years.&#160; Mr. So has served as a trustee of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, New Asia College since 1994.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	ANDREW SO joined the Company in August 2009 and has been a director since February 25, 2012.&#160; Mr. So currently holds the position of Chief Operating Officer and oversees the Company&#8217;s daily operations, and has also held the positions of Deputy Chairman of the Board and President since March 20, 2015.&#160; Mr. So graduated with distinctions in 2008 from the University of Toronto, Canada, with a Bachelor of Commerce degree (BComm).&#160; From 2008 to 2009, prior to his employment with the Company, Mr. So worked as a Derivatives Analyst at State Street Trust Company Canada, Toronto, Canada. Mr. So graduated from the MBA Program of Hong Kong University of Science and Technology in the Fall of 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	53
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage54"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	ALBERT SO was appointed as the Chief Financial Officer and Secretary of the Company on March 27, 2009.&#160; He was appointed Treasurer and Financial Controller of the Company on March 20, 2015.&#160; Mr. So was previously employed as the Financial Controller of the Company in January 2008 and as a management trainee of the Company in November 2004.&#160; Mr. So has been a director since March 1, 2013.&#160; Prior to his employment as a management trainee of the Company, Mr. So was a student. &#160;Mr. So is a Certified Management Accountant and Financial Risk Manager, and received a Master degree in Business Administration from Heriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom, and a Bachelor degree in Mathematics from Simon Fraser University in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	KIM WAH CHUNG has been a director since September 21, 1994.&#160; Mr. Chung has been employed by us since 1981 and currently holds the position of Director of Engineering and Research and Development.&#160; Mr. Chung is responsible for all research projects and product development.&#160; Mr. Chung&#8217;s entire engineering career has been spent with Bonso, and he has been involved in all of our major product developments.&#160; Mr. Chung graduated with honors in 1981 from the Chinese University of Hong Kong with a Bachelor of Science degree in electronics.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	WOO-PING FOK was elected to our Board of Directors on September 21, 1994.&#160; Mr. Fok has practiced law in Hong Kong since 1991 and is a Consultant with Messrs. C.K. Mok &amp; Co.&#160; Mr. Fok&#8217;s major areas of practice include conveyancing and real property law, corporations and business law, commercial transactions and international trade with a special emphasis in China trade matters.&#160; Mr. Fok was admitted to the Canadian Bar as a Barrister &amp; Solicitor in December 1987 and was a partner in the law firm of Woo &amp; Fok, a Canadian law firm with its head office in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada.&#160; In 1991, Mr. Fok was qualified to practice as a Solicitor of England &amp; Wales, a Solicitor of Hong Kong and a Barrister &amp; Solicitor of Australian Capital Territory.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	HENRY F. SCHLUETER has been a director since October 2001 and has been our Assistant Secretary since October 6, 1988.&#160; Since 1992, Mr. Schlueter has been the Managing Director of Schlueter &amp; Associates, P.C., a law firm, practicing in the areas of securities, mergers and acquisitions, finance and corporate law.&#160; Mr. Schlueter has served as our United States corporate and securities counsel since 1988.&#160; From 1989 to 1991, prior to establishing Schlueter &amp; Associates, P.C., Mr. Schlueter was a partner in the Denver, Colorado office of Kutak Rock (formerly Kutak, Rock &amp; Campbell), and from 1984 to 1989, he was a partner in the Denver office of Nelson &amp; Harding.&#160; Mr. Schlueter is a member of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the Colorado and Denver Bar Associations and the Wyoming State Bar. Mr. Schlueter is registered with the Hong Kong Law Society as a Foreign Lawyer.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Anthony So, the Company&#8217;s Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Directors is the father of Andrew So, the Company&#8217;s President and Chief Operating Officer, and Albert So, the Company&#8217;s Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer and Secretary.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	No arrangement or understanding exists between any such director or officer and any other persons pursuant to which any director or executive officer was elected as a director or executive officer.&#160; Our directors are elected annually and serve until their successors take office or until their death, resignation or removal.&#160; The executive officers serve at the pleasure of the Board of Directors.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	54
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">

</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage55"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Compensation
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The aggregate amount of compensation paid by us and our subsidiaries during the year ended March 31, 2016 to all directors, former directors and officers as a group for services in all capacities was $1,517,000.&#160; Total compensation for the benefit of Anthony So was $857,000, for the benefit of Kim Wah Chung was $170,000, for the benefit of Andrew So was $249,000, for the benefit of Albert So was $181,000 and for the benefit of Henry F. Schlueter was an aggregate of $60,000.&#160; The $60,000 listed as having been paid for the benefit of Mr. Schlueter was paid to his law firm, Schlueter &amp; Associates, P.C., for legal services rendered.&#160; The amount for the year ended March 31, 2016, included unpaid vacation payments of $57,000, $10,000, and $12,000 for Mr. Anthony So, Mr. Kim Wah Chung, and Mr. Albert So, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	We did not set aside or accrue any amounts to provide pension, retirement or similar benefits for directors and officers for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2016, other than contributions to our Provident Fund Plan, which aggregated $18,000 for officers and directors.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Employment Agreements
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	We have employment agreements with Anthony So and Kim Wah Chung.&#160; Mr. So&#8217;s employment agreement provides for a maximum yearly salary of approximately $800,000 per year plus bonus, and Mr. Chung&#8217;s employment agreement provides for a maximum yearly salary of approximately $200,000 per year plus bonus.&#160; The initial term of the employment agreements expired on March 31, 2013 (&#8220;Initial Term&#8221;); however, the employment agreements have been renewed under a provision in the agreements that provides for automatic renewal for successive one year periods, unless at least 90 days prior to the expiration of the Initial Term or any renewal term, either party gives written notice to the other party specifically electing to terminate the agreement.&#160; One of the properties of the Group in Hong Kong is also provided to Mr. So as part of his compensation.&#160; Mr. So&#8217;s employment agreement contains a provision under which the Company will be obligated to pay Mr. So all compensation for the remainder of his employment agreement and five times his annual salary and bonus compensation if a change of control, as defined in his employment agreement, occurs.&#160; Both employment agreements with Anthony So and Kim Wah Chung were renewed automatically, and the respective employment agreements will expire on March 31, 2017, unless automatically renewed.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;

<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Directors
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Except as mentioned above, our directors do not receive any additional monetary compensation for serving in their capacities.&#160; All directors are reimbursed for all reasonable expenses incurred in connection with their services as a director.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Employee retirement benefits
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<TABLE ID="B71D4C3B64744787A3AD3E8259761DD6" CLASS="DSPFLISTTABLE" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; WIDTH: 100%" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0">
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 36PT; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; ALIGN: RIGHT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: AUTO; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	With effect from January 1, 1988, BEL, a wholly-owned foreign subsidiary of the Company in Hong Kong, implemented a defined contribution plan (the &#8220;Plan&#8221;) with a major international assurance company to provide life insurance and retirement benefits for its employees.&#160; All permanent full time employees who joined BEL before December 2000, excluding factory workers, are eligible to join the provident fund plan.&#160; Eligible employees of the Plan are required to contribute 5% of their monthly salary, while BEL is required to contribute from 5% to 10% based on the eligible employee&#8217;s salary, depending on the number of years of the eligible employee&#8217;s service.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-LEFT: 36PT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	The Mandatory Provident Fund (the &#8220;MPF&#8221;) was introduced by the Hong Kong Government and commenced in December 2000.&#160; BEL joined the MPF by implementing a plan with a major international assurance company.&#160; All permanent Hong Kong full time employees who joined BEL on or after December 2000, excluding factory workers, are eligible to join the MPF.&#160; Eligible employees&#8217; and the employer&#8217;s contributions to the MPF are both at 5% of the eligible employee&#8217;s monthly salary and are subject to a maximum mandatory contribution of HK$1,000 (US$128) monthly.&#160; The maximum mandatory contribution was increased to HK$1,250 (US$160) monthly starting from June 1, 2012.&#160; The maximum mandatory contribution was increased to HK$1,500 (US$192) per month starting from June 1, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-LEFT: 36PT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Pursuant to the relevant PRC regulations, the Group is required to make contributions for each employee, at rates based upon the employee&#8217;s standard salary base as determined by the local Social Security Bureau, to a defined contribution retirement scheme organized by the local Social Security Bureau in respect of the retirement benefits for the Group&#8217;s employees in the PRC.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	56
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage57"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<TABLE ID="40CADD2F641D47FAA600DF47C450F0B0" CLASS="DSPFLISTTABLE" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; WIDTH: 100%" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0">
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 36PT; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; ALIGN: RIGHT">
	(b)
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: AUTO; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The contributions to each of the above schemes are recognized as employee benefit expense when they are due and are charged to the consolidated statement of income (loss).&#160; The Group&#8217;s total contributions to the above schemes for the years ended March 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 amounted to approximately $758,000, $693,000 and $293,000, respectively.&#160; The Group has no other obligation to make payments in respect of retirement benefits of the employees.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Board Practices
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	All directors hold office until our next annual meeting of shareholders or until their respective successors are duly elected and qualified or their positions are earlier vacated by resignation or otherwise.&#160; All executive officers are appointed by the Board and serve at the pleasure of the Board.&#160; There are no director service contracts providing for benefits upon termination of employment or directorship.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	NASDAQ Exemptions and Home Country Practices
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	NASDAQ Marketplace Rule 4350 provides that foreign private issuers may elect to follow certain home country corporate governance practices so long as they provide NASDAQ with a letter from outside counsel in its home country certifying that the issuer 's corporate governance practices are not prohibited by home country law.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000">
	On July 19, 2005, we submitted a letter to NASDAQ certifying that certain of Bonso&#8217;s corporate governance practices are not prohibited by the relevant
</FONT>
	laws of the British Virgin Islands.&#160; We will follow British Virgin Island law in respect to the following requirements:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<TABLE ID="09AB7D0CD8D04170A5BCDD6E6B78FACA" CLASS="DSPFLISTTABLE" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; WIDTH: 100%" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0">
<TR>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 36PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: WINGDINGS; WIDTH: 36PT; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; COLOR: #000000; ALIGN: RIGHT">
	&#167;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: AUTO; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	A majority of Bonso&#8217;s Board of Directors will not be independent;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<TABLE ID="8DCD2E7F6B994C8E8EE952532379A9F3" CLASS="DSPFLISTTABLE" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; WIDTH: 100%" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0">
<TR>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 36PT">
</TD>

	&#167;
</TD>

</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">

</TD>

<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">

</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">

<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">

</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Audit Committee
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Mr. Woo-Ping Fok is the sole member of the Audit Committee and Mr. Schlueter serves as an ad hoc member.&#160; Mr. Fok is &#8220;independent&#8221; as defined in the NASDAQ listing standards, and Mr. Schlueter may not be considered &#8220;independent&#8221; since his law firm serves as Bonso&#8217;s United States counsel.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The Audit Committee was established to:&#160; (i) review and approve the scope of audit procedures employed by our independent auditors; (ii) review and approve the audit reports rendered by our independent auditors; (iii) approve the audit fee charged by the independent auditors; (iv) report to the Board of Directors with respect to such matters; (v) recommend the selection of independent auditors; and (vi) discharge such other responsibilities as may be delegated to it from time to time by the Board of Directors.&#160; Effective as of June 30, 2015, the Board of Directors adopted an amended charter for its Audit Committee.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;

<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Employees
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	At March 31, 2016, we employed a total of 415 persons, as compared to 528 persons at March 31, 2015 and 663 persons at March 31, 2014; 8 employees in Hong Kong (8 in 2015 and 12 in 2014) and 407 employees in China (520 in 2015 and 651 in 2014).&#160; Employees are not covered by collective bargaining agreements.&#160; We consider our global labor practices and employee relations to be good.
</DIV>

<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	58
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage59"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Stock Option and Bonus Plans
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	The 1996 Stock Option Plan
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In October 1996, our stockholders adopted the 1996 Stock Option Plan (the &#8220;Employees&#8217; Plan&#8221;), which provided for the grant of options to purchase an aggregate of not more than 400,000 shares of our common stock.&#160; In January 2000, our shareholders approved the proposal of the Board of Directors to increase from 400,000 to 900,000 in the aggregate the number of options to purchase common stock under the Employees&#8217; Plan.&#160; The purpose of the Employees&#8217; Plan is to make options available to management and employees in order to encourage them to secure or increase on reasonable terms their stock ownership and to encourage them to remain with the Company.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The Employees&#8217; Plan is administered by a committee appointed by the Board of Directors which determines the persons to be granted options under the Employees&#8217; Plan, the number of shares subject to each option, the exercise price of each option and the option period, subject to the requirement that no option may be exercisable more than ten years after the date of grant.&#160; The exercise price of an option may be less than the fair market value of the underlying shares of common stock.&#160; No options granted under the Employees&#8217; Plan are transferable by the optionee other than by will or the laws of descent and distribution, and each option will be exercisable during the lifetime of the optionee only by such optionee.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The exercise price of an option granted pursuant to the Employees&#8217; Plan may be paid in cash, by the surrender of options, in common stock, in other property, including the optionee&#8217;s promissory note, or by a combination of the above, at our discretion.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2016, no options were granted under the Employees&#8217; Plan and as of July 15, 2016, there were no options outstanding which were issued under that plan.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	The 2004 Stock Option Plan
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	On March 23, 2004, our stockholders adopted the 2004 Stock Option Plan (the &#8220;2004 Plan&#8221;), which provided for the grant of up to six hundred thousand (600,000) shares of the Company&#8217;s common stock in the form of stock options, subject to certain adjustments as described in the 2004 Plan. At the Annual Meeting of Shareholders held on March 20, 2015, the shareholders approved an amendment to the 2004 Plan to increase the number of shares that could be granted from 600,000 to 850,000.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The purpose of the 2004 Plan is to secure key employees to remain in the employ of the Company and to encourage such employees to secure or increase on reasonable terms their common stock ownership in the Company.&#160; The Company believes that the 2004 Plan promotes continuity of management and increased incentive and personal interest in the welfare of the Company.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	59
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #404040; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #404040" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage60"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The 2004 Plan is administered by a committee appointed by the Board of Directors, which consists of at least two but not more than three members of the Board, one of whom shall be a non-employee of the Company.&#160; The committee members currently are Anthony So and Woo-Ping Fok.&#160; The committee determines the specific terms of the options granted, including the employees to be granted options under the plan, the number of shares subject to each option grant, the exercise price of each option and the option period, subject to the requirement that no option may be exercisable more than 10 years after the date of grant.&#160; The exercise price of an option may be less than the fair market value of the underlying shares of common stock.&#160; No options granted under the plan will be transferable by the optionee other than by will or the laws of descent and distribution, and each option will be exercisable during the lifetime of the optionee only by the optionee.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The exercise price of an option granted pursuant to the 2004 Plan may be paid in cash, by the surrender of options, in common stock, in other property, including a promissory note from the optionee, or by a combination of the above, at the discretion of the Committee.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	As of March 31, 2016, 850,000 options, all with an exercise price of $1.50 per share, had been granted to officers and directors of the Company under the 2004 Plan, all of which remained outstanding as of July 15, 2016.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	2004 Stock Bonus Plan
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	On September 7, 2004, our stockholders adopted the 2004 Stock Bonus Plan (the &#8220;Stock Bonus Plan&#8221;), which authorizes the issuance of up to five hundred thousand (500,000) shares of the Company&#8217;s Common Stock in the form of a stock bonus.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The purpose of this Stock Bonus Plan is to:&#160; (i) induce key employees to remain in the employ of the Company or of any subsidiary of the Company; (ii) encourage such employees to secure or increase their stock ownership in the Company; and (iii) reward employees, non-employee directors, advisors and consultants for services rendered, or to be rendered, to or for the benefit of the Company or any of its subsidiaries.&#160; The Company believes that the Stock Bonus Plan will promote continuity of management and increased incentive and personal interest in the welfare of the Company.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	The Stock Bonus Plan is administered by a committee appointed by the Board of Directors which consists of at least two but not more than three members of the Board, one of whom shall be a non-employee of the Company.&#160; The Committee members currently are Anthony So and Woo-Ping Fok.&#160; The Committee has the authority, in its sole discretion:&#160; (i) to determine the parties to receive bonus stock, the times when they shall receive such awards, the number of shares to be issued and the time, terms and conditions of the issuance of any such shares; (ii) to construe and interpret the terms of the Stock Bonus Plan; (iii) to establish, amend and rescind rules and regulations for the administration of the Stock Bonus Plan; and (iv) to make all other determinations necessary or advisable for administering the Stock Bonus Plan.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	As of March 31, 2016, no shares had been granted under the Stock Bonus Plan.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN'; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
	60
</DIV>

<EFX_SECURITY_OWNERS>
<A NAME="FIS_SECURITY_OWNERS"></A>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Item 7.&#160; Major Shareholders and Related Party Transactions
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Major shareholders
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	We are not directly or indirectly owned or controlled by any foreign government or by another corporation.&#160; The following table sets forth, as of July 15, 2016, beneficial ownership of our common stock by each person, to the best of our knowledge, known to own beneficially 5% or more of our common stock outstanding as of such date.&#160; Except as otherwise indicated, all shares are owned directly and hold equal voting rights.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<EFX_BENEFICIAL_OWNERS>

<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Related Party Transactions
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	During the fiscal years ended March 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, we paid Schlueter &amp; Associates, P.C. an aggregate of $84,000, $55,000 and $60,000, respectively, for legal fees.&#160; Mr. Henry F. Schlueter, a director of the Company, is the Managing Director of Schlueter &amp; Associates, P.C.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2015, Anthony So, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, made an interest-free loan to Bonso Advanced Technology Limited, a subsidiary of Bonso Electronics International Inc., in the principal amount of HK$4,200,000 (approximately US$538,000 as of the date of the loan).&#160; The loan is payable in 48 equal monthly installments of HK$87,500 each (approximately US$11,000), which commenced on October 31, 2014. As of March 31, 2016, the Company had repaid approximately $201,000 to Mr. Anthony So, and the balance of the loan due to Mr. Anthony So was approximately $337,000.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2015, one of our subsidiaries in Shenzhen, PRC entered into a rental agreement with a director and shareholder, Mr. Anthony So, for three apartment units located in Shenzhen, PRC for office usage.&#160; Mr. Anthony So is the sole owner of these three apartment units.&#160; The monthly rental payment is approximately $2,000, and the total rent paid to Mr. Anthony So during the fiscal year ended March 31, 2016 was approximately $24,000 (2015: $10,000).
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	&#160;

	During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2015, one of our subsidiaries in Xinxing, PRC entered into a rental agreement with a director and shareholder, Mr. Andrew So, for an apartment unit located in Xinxing, PRC for staff quarters.&#160; Mr. Andrew So is the sole owner of this apartment unit.&#160; The monthly rental payment is approximately $480, and the total rent paid to Mr. Andrew So during the fiscal year ended March 31, 2015 was approximately $5,000.

<EFX_LISTING>

	Item 9.&#160; The Offer and Listing
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Offer and Listing Details
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Our common stock is traded only in the United States over-the-counter market.&#160; It is quoted on the NASDAQ Capital Market under the trading symbol &#8220;BNSO.&#8221;&#160; The following table sets forth, for the periods indicated, the range of high and low closing sales prices per share reported by NASDAQ.&#160; The quotations represent prices between dealers and do not include retail markup, markdown or commissions and may not necessarily represent actual transactions.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">

<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	On July 15, 2016, the closing price of our common stock was $1.34.&#160; Of the 5,577,639 shares of common stock issued as of June 30, 2016, 5,154,431 shares were outstanding, 2,412,370 shares were held in the United States by 152 holders of record and 423,208 shares were held by the Company as treasury stock.&#160; We have 165 shareholders of record.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Transfer and Warrant Agent
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>

	The transfer agent and registrar for the common stock is Computershare, 1745 Gardena Avenue #200, Glendale, California 91204.

<EFX_ADDITIONAL_INFORMATION>
<A NAME="FIS_ADDITIONAL_INFORMATION"></A>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Item 10.&#160; Additional Information
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
	Share Capital
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	Our authorized capital is $170,000, consisting of 23,333,334 shares of common stock, $0.003 par value per share, and 10,000,000 authorized shares of preferred stock, $0.01 par value, divided into 2,500,000 shares each of class A preferred stock, class B preferred stock, class C preferred stock and class D preferred stock.&#160; Information with respect to the number of shares of common stock outstanding at the beginning and at the end of the last three fiscal years is presented in the Consolidated Statements of Changes in Stockholders&#8217; Equity for the fiscal years ended March 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 included herein in Item 18.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
<BR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	At July 15, 2016, there were 5,577,639 shares of our common stock issued, 5,154,431 shares were outstanding, and 423,208 shares were held by the Company in treasury.&#160; All shares were fully paid.&#160; In addition, we had outstanding 850,000 options to purchase common stock as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; LINE-HEIGHT: 1; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT: 1">
